resources.string:
1. Avoid being overweight. Have balanced, healthy diet rather than “Special diabetic foods”


2. Daily energy intake must be estimated after considering such factors as age, sex, actual weight in relation to desirable weight, activity and occupation.


3. Eat small meals (5-6 meals) every 2-3 hours rather than a large three meals a day to keep the energy levels high


4. Include carbohydrates from foods high in fibre e.g. whole grains (unpolished cereals and millets), whole pulses and legumes like grams, soy, peas, beans, etc.


5. Proteins should provide 12-15 % of the total energy intake for people with diabetes. Proteins from vegetable sources like pulses, soy, grams, peas, low fat milk, low fat curds, fish and lean meats are recommended


6. It is advised to consume less than 10% of calories from saturated fat and less than 300mg of cholesterol/day.


7. A mixture of oil is preferred than single oil. Poly unsaturated fatty acids and monounsaturated fatty acids containing vegetable oils (sunflower oil, groundnut oil, corn oil, gingelly oil) are preferred than hydrogenated fat (ghee, butter, etc.)


8. Limit salt and salted foods. Sodium intake should not be no more than 6gm daily. Diabetics are susceptible to high blood pressure. For persons with hypertension and diabetes, the intake should be reduced to less than 3 g/ day.


9. Drink plenty of water and exercise regularly. Exercise increases sensitivity to insulin and helps to improve blood-sugar control.


10. Avoid junk foods, aerated drinks and stick to natural drinks like fresh juice and water.


11. Avoid ‘fasting’ and ‘feasting’.
